From GTC to Website Building with AI Tools

Summary

In this episode, Jason Hand and Ryan MacLean discuss their experiences at NVIDIA‚Äôs GTC conference in San Jose, where over 25,000 attendees gathered for what they described as the ‚ÄòSuper Bowl of AI conferences.‚Äô They share insights from the conference, highlighting the shift from curiosity to practical implementation in the AI industry, with many attendees seeking guidance on production readiness, hallucination detection, and security concerns. Jason then demonstrates how he used Claude Code to create a website for their AI tools experiments project, complete with a feedback form that sends data to Datadog.

Jump To

  • Introduction and catching up since GTC conference
  • Jason‚Äôs experience attending 15+ sessions at GTC
  • Physical AI applications at GTC: robots and autonomous vehicles
  • Jason‚Äôs experience at the Datadog booth and common concerns
  • Wallet attacks and API cost management concerns
  • Demonstrating the new website with feedback form
  • Discussing improvements to the Ignite Karaoke project
  • Showcase of the improved Vinyl Viewer application
  • Demonstrating the enhanced A Call of Cats adoption application
  • Wrapping up and plans for next episode

Resources

  • Claude Code
  • Windsurf IDE
  • Ignite Karaoke GitHub Repository
  • Vinyl Viewer GitHub Repository
  • Datadog
  • NVIDIA GTC Conference

Key Takeaways

  • The AI industry is shifting from curiosity to practical implementation, with GTC attendance growing to over 25,000 people
  • Many organizations are concerned with hallucination detection, security, and cost management as they move AI projects to production
  • Claude Code can efficiently help build websites and web applications with features like feedback forms and API integrations
  • AI tools like Claude Code can resolve long-standing bugs and improve UI/UX in existing projects
  • The concept of ‚Äúwallet attacks‚Äù (competitors trying to exhaust your API quotas) is an emerging concern in AI deployment
  • Serverless functions can help overcome CORS limitations when building web applications that integrate with third-party APIs
